meta.title: Ischemic Heart Disease - Risk Factors & Dyslipidemia

questions.text: Which is not a feature of Metabolic syndrome:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High LDL Metabolic syndrome (also known as syndrome X)

Highyeild:

NCEP-ATP III CRITERIA FOR METABOLIC SYNDROME - Three or more of the following 1. Central obesity: waist circumference > 102 cm in males, > 88 cm in Females (>90cm in males and >80cm in females in the South Asian population as per harmonizing definition) 2. Hypertriglyceridemia: > 150 mg%, 3. Low HDL cholesterol: < 40 mg% (male), < 50 mg% (Female) 4. Hypertension: > 130 mm systolic or > 85% diastole 5. Fasting plasma glucose > 100 mg% or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Central obesity: waist circumference > 102 cm in males, > 88 cm in Females - Option B- Fasting plasma glucose > 100 mg% or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes Option D- Hypertension: > 130 mm systolic or > 85% diastole-

questions.text: Mr. Hrithik is undergoing an exercise stress test. You know that as he progresses through his stress test his myocardium will require more oxygen. How does the normal (non-diseased) heart respond to meet its higher oxygen demand?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased myocardial oxygen extraction during near-constant coronary blood flow

options.label: B
options.text: Increased oxygen extraction from the ventricular chambers

options.label: C
options.text: Relative expansion of the diastolic period allowing the Increased coronary flow

options.label: D
options.text: Vasodilation of intramyocardial coronary vessels Leading to increased coronary blood flow

questions.correct_answer: D. Vasodilation of intramyocardial coronary vessels Leading to increased coronary blood flow
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vasodilation of intramyocardial coronary vessels Leading to increased coronary blood flow Normal coronary circulation is dominated and controlled By the heart’s requirements for oxygen. This need is met by the ability of the coronary vascular bed to vary its resistance (and, therefore, blood flow) considerably while the myocardium extracts a high and relatively fixed percentage of oxygen. Normally, intramyocardial resistance vessels demonstrate a great capacity for dilation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . The epicardial coronary arteries, in their normal state, provide only trivial resistance to flow. Option B. Myocardial oxygen extraction is relatively fixed. Option C. During tachycardia, the diastolic period is shortened relative to the systolic.

questions.text: You are evaluating Mr. Suresh, an 87-year-old man with only a history of hypertension. He reports classic exertional angina. On coronary angiography, you find no coronary artery disease with normal caliber vessels. You do not have a 50-mmHg mean gradient across his aortic valve, however, with a calculated aortic valve area of 0.6 cm2. The echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular systolic function with left ventricular concentric hypertrophy. Which of these physiologic processes explains Mr. Suresh's angina?

options.label: B
options.text: Mismatch in myocardial oxygen supply and demand

questions.correct_answer: B. Mismatch in myocardial oxygen supply and demand
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mismatch in myocardial oxygen supply and demand Myocardial ischemia also can occur if myocardial oxygen Demands are markedly increased and particularly when coronary blood flow may be limited, as occurs in severe left ventricular hypertrophy due to aortic stenosis. The latter can present with angina that is indistinguishable from that caused by coronary atherosclerosis largely due to subendocardial ischemia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . He doesn’t have any history of arrhythmias Option C. There is no history of pericarditis. Also, pericarditis does not present with exertional chest pain usually. Option D . There are no factors predisposing him to vasospasms.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man went for a diagnostic coronary angiography after an abnormal stress test. Arterial access was obtained easily in the right femoral artery, and the angiography was completed with 35 ccs of iodinated contrast dye. Fortunately, no significant coronary stenosis was noted. Seven days later, he returns to the emergency room with abdominal pain and nausea. He reports that his urine Output has been poor recently. Examination reveals a slight fever (38.3°C) and livedo reticularis on his lower extremities. Laboratory studies show a creatinine of 2.7 mg/dl (previously 1.1), a white blood cell count of 10,500/ml with 21% eosinophils, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 92 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atheroembolic renal disease This patient’s clinical scenario is most consistent with another embolic renal disease. Atheroemboli in the kidney is strongly associated with aortic aneurysmal disease and renal artery stenosis . Most clinical cases can be linked to precipitating events, such as angiography, vascular surgery, anticoagulation with heparin, thrombolytic therapy, or trauma.

Highyeild:

- Clinical manifestations of Atheroembolic renal disease commonly develop between 1 and 14 days after an inciting event and may continue to develop for weeks thereafter. Systemic embolic disease manifestations, such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss, are present in less than half of patients, although cutaneous manifestations including livedo reticularis and localized toe gangren e may be more common. Worsening hypertension and deteriorating kidney functio n are common. Typical laboratory findings include rising creatinine , transient eosinophilia (60–80% of cases), elevated sedimentation rate , and hypocomplementemia (15% of cases).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . It would be unusual to develop interstitial nephritis without exposure to a new medication, and other than eosinophilia the laboratory abnormalities are not supportive in this case. Option C .Likewise, the sudden development of hypereosinophilic syndrome in a 75-year-old man would be highly unlikely. Finally, while Churg-Strauss syndrome is a small-to-medium vessel vasculitis associated with renal dysfunction and eosinophilia, almost all patients experience atopy and asthma-like lung disease, which are Absent in this patient. Option D. Contrast-induced nephropathy is not associated with fever, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, eosinophilia, or livedo reticularis of the lower extremities.

:

Clinical manifestations of Atheroembolic renal disease commonly develop between 1 and 14 days after an inciting event and may continue to develop for weeks thereafter. Systemic embolic disease manifestations, such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss, are present in less than half of patients, although cutaneous manifestations including livedo reticularis and localized toe gangren e may be more common. Worsening hypertension and deteriorating kidney functio n are common. Typical laboratory findings include rising creatinine , transient eosinophilia (60–80% of cases), elevated sedimentation rate , and hypocomplementemia (15% of cases).

questions.text: A 60 yrs male came to the hospital with a history of ischemic heart disease, he had a high level of low-density lipoprotein. What is the significance of low-density lipoprotein in atherosclerosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of control of vascular tone

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of maintenance of antithrombotic surface

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of control of inflammation and diapedesis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a condition in which there is an inadequate supply of blood and oxygen to a portion of the myocardium; it typically occurs when there is an imbalance between myocardial oxygen supply and demand. The most common cause of myocardial ischemia is atherosclerotic disease of an epicardial coronary artery (or arteries) sufficient to cause a regional reduction in myocardial blood flow and inadequate perfusion of the myocardium supplied by the involved coronary artery. Genetic factors, a high-fat and energy-rich diet, smoking, and a sedentary lifestyle are associated with the emergence of IHD. Obesity, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes mellitus are increasing and are powerful risk factors for IHD.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Loss of control of vascular tone: it results when there is an increased level of low-density lipoprotein causing atherosclerosis. Option B . Loss of maintenance of antithrombotic surface: it results when there is an increased level of low-density lipoprotein causing atherosclerosis. Option C . Loss of control of inflammation and diapedesis: it results when there is an increased level of low-density lipoprotein causing atherosclerosis .

questions.text: 50 yrs male with a known case of hypertension and diabetes was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease, what are the factors that determine myocardial oxygen consumption?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a condition in which there is an inadequate supply of blood and oxygen to a portion of the myocardium; it typically occurs when there is an imbalance between myocardial oxygen supply and demand. The most common cause of myocardial ischemia is atherosclerotic disease of an epicardial coronary artery ( or arteries) sufficient to cause a regional reduction in myocardial blood flow and inadequate perfusion of the myocardium supplied by the involved coronary artery. Genetic factors, a high-fat and energy-rich diet, smoking, and a sedentary lifestyle are associated with the emergence of IHD. Obesity, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes mellitus are increasing and are powerful risk factors for IHD. These trends are occurring in the general context of population growth and as a result of the increase in the average age of the world’s population.

Highyeild:

The major determinant of myocardial oxygen demand are: 1. Heart rate 2. Myocardial contractility. 3. Myocardial tension (Stress)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Heart rate: it is the determinant of myocardial oxygen consumption. Option B . Myocardial contractility: it is the determinant of myocardial oxygen consumption. Option C . Myocardial tension (Stress): it is the determinant of myocardial oxygen consumption.

questions.text: A 60 yrs man was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease, what are the causes of decreased myocardium perfusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Luminal reduction due to atherosclerotic plaques

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a condition in which there is an inadequate supply of blood and oxygen to a portion of the myocardium; it typically occurs when there is an imbalance between myocardial oxygen supply and demand. The most common cause of myocardial ischemia is atherosclerotic disease of an epicardial coronary artery (or arteries) sufficient to cause a regional reduction in myocardial blood flow and inadequate perfusion of the myocardium supplied by the involved coronary artery. Genetic factors, a high-fat and energy-rich diet, smoking, and a sedentary lifestyle are associated with the emergence of IHD.

Highyeild:

Causes for reduced myocardial perfusion in the basal state: 1. luminal reduction due to atherosclerotic plaques. 2. spasm of coronary arteries. 3. ostial narrowing is seen in aortitis. 4. coronary emboli 5. severe left ventricular hypertrophy. 6. anemia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- luminal reduction due to atherosclerotic plaques: it causes a decrease in myocardial perfusion. Option B- spasm of coronary arteries : it causes a decrease in myocardial perfusion. Option C- ostial narrowing is seen in aortitis: it causes a decrease in myocardial perfusion.
